Promotion effect of Al species on silica-supported cesium oxide catalyst in the vapor-phase dehydration of 1,2-propanediol to propylene oxide Masafumi Morooka Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation a Enggah Kurniawan Writing – review & editing Visualization a Junji Okamura Validation Data curation b Yusei Nagamura Validation b Takayoshi Hara Data curation Validation a Takashi Kojima Data curation Validation a Yasuhiro Yamada Validation Supervision a Satoshi Sato Writing – review & editing Validation Project administration Methodology Conceptualization a ⁎ a Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba 263-8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University Chiba 263-8522 Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba 263-8522, Japan b Nippon Shokubai Co. Ltd., Suita, Osaka 564-0034, Japan Nippon Shokubai Co. Ltd., Suita Osaka 564-0034 Japan Nippon Shokubai Co. Ltd., Suita, Osaka 564-0034, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. The introduction of Al into SiO2-supported cesium oxide (Cs/SiO2) promoted catalytic activity for the dehydration of 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) to propylene oxide (PO). This improvement was attributed to the promotion of CsNO3 decomposition and the ability of Al to keep the morphology of the SiO2-supported catalyst, even though the Al component slightly reduced the concentration of the base site. The optimum molar component of Al was proven to improve the activity of Cs/SiO2 catalyst, while maintaining a low rate of side reactions, such as isomerization of PO to allyl alcohol and dehydration of 1,2-PDO to propanal. Several parameters, such as reaction temperature, contact time, Cs8Al2 content, and Al molar component influenced catalytic activity and product distributions. The poisoning experiment by use of CO2 revealed the importance of the base sites of Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst, while the role of acid sites was negligible as confirmed by the poisoning experiment with NH3. Graphical Abstract Keywords 1,2-Propanediol Propylene oxide Silica-supported cesium-aluminum oxide Vapor-phase dehydration Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The growing production of the bio-diesel industry as one of the most promising alternatives to fossil fuels directly correlates with the availability of its by-product, namely glycerol [1–3]. Glycerol is a C3 chemical that provides access to several important compounds, such as 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO), allyl alcohol (AAL), hydroxyacetone (acetol), 3-hydroxy-2-butanone (acrolein), and acrylic acid [4–6]. The strategy of converting glycerol to these value-added chemicals is essential since it aligns with the effort to valorize biomass-derived compounds. In addition, efficient glycerol conversion transforms a by-product in a chemical industry into a promising commodity. Therefore, efficient technology for converting glycerol and its derivatives, such as catalytic transformation, is highly sought. 1,2-PDO is an important glycerol derivative that is used as a non-toxic antifreeze, moisturizer, surfactant, a monomer for polyester, preservative, and as an additive in paints, detergents, cosmetics, and foods [7,8]. Numerous reports have suggested that 1,2-PDO can be obtained from glycerol via catalytic hydrogenolysis [9–14]. 1,2-PDO is also a promising compound to produce propylene oxide (PO), a key chemical in foams, coatings, and adhesives industries [15]. The industrial strategy for the PO formation via the chlorohydrin process, which is considered the oldest method for PO production, suffers from a series of drawbacks, such as the utilization of expensive oxidants, corrosive natures of Cl-based salt, and environmental issues with the waste [16]. Even though several alternatives have been developed for the production of PO, these strategies mainly rely on fossil fuel-derived propylene [17,18]. Directing attention towards a more benign and sustainable process by using a biomass-derived chemical is important to provide an alternative to fossil fuel-derived processes in PO production. In this regard, the dehydrative epoxidation of biomass-derived 1,2-PDO could be viewed as a promising strategy for the green and sustainable production of PO. Several reports have shown that supported base catalysts, such as Cs/SiO2 and K/SiO2, act as efficient catalysts for converting 1,2-PDO to PO [19–21]. The presence of the base sites, originating from the Cs and K components, on SiO2 support has been reported to play a crucial role in the dehydrative epoxidation of 1,2-PDO to PO. In line with these works, we have also employed a CsH2PO4/SiO2 catalyst for the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to AAL [22]. We have found that the AAL formation is initiated by the formation of PO using the base sites of the catalyst. This PO is then converted to AAL using the acid and base sites of the CsH2PO4/SiO2 catalyst. The acid site of the catalyst has also been reported to facilitate the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to propanal (PAL) [23,24]. In addition, several side reactions to generate products, such as acetone (AC), acetol, propylene (C3’), and 2-ethyl-4-methyl-1,3-dioxolane (dioxolane), have also been reported in the dehydration of 1,2-PDO ( Scheme 1) [23]. Due to the variety of products that can potentially be generated, the acid and base properties of the catalyst need to be tailored for efficient production of PO from 1,2-PDO. The SiO2-supported Cs catalysts have also been utilized for the aldol condensation of several esters, such as methyl acetate and methyl propionate, with formaldehyde [25–28]. Interestingly, these reports have suggested that the addition of a second metal component, such as Al and Zr could enhance the performance of the Cs/SiO2 catalysts in this aldol condensation. The presence of a second metal component improves the dispersion of Cs species, which is beneficial for the aldol condensation. Considering that the Cs species is reported as the origin for the base sites in the Cs/SiO2 catalysts, the improvement of Cs dispersion could also improve the dispersion of the base sites in the catalyst. These properties could potentially be applied to enhancing the catalytic activity of Cs/SiO2 catalyst in the dehydrative epoxidation of 1,2-PDO to PO. In this work, the Al component was introduced to the Cs/SiO2 catalyst, and the promotion effect of this Al component was investigated for the dehydrative epoxidation of 1,2-PDO to PO. The effect of the Al component on the transformation and properties of the catalyst was unraveled using several analysis techniques. In addition, the effect of the Al component in the dehydrative epoxidation of 1,2-PDO was analyzed under different reaction conditions. The change in the catalytic activity was also investigated in the presence of CO2, NH3, 2,6-, and 3,5-dimethylpyridine (DMP) to reveal the role of acid and base sites of the SiO2-supported Cs modified with Al. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Silica support (CARiACT Q-10, specific surface area (SA) of 240 m2 g−1) was supplied by Fuji Silysia Chemical Ltd. Cesium nitrate (CsNO3), aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3 .9H2O), zirconyl nitrate dihydrate lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate, calcium nitrate tetrahydrate, magnesium nitrate hexahydrate, and potassium nitrate were purchased from Fujifilm Wako Chemicals, Corp. Yttrium(III) nitrate hexahydrate was purchased from Sigma Aldrich, Co. LLC. The SiO2-supported cesium-aluminum, denoted as aCs8Al x /SiO2, where a and x represent the loaded oxides (8Cs2O-xAl2O3), Cs8Al x , content in wt% and the molar component of Al, respectively, was prepared through the impregnation method by adjusting the amount of CsNO3, Al(NO3)3 .9H2O, and SiO2. For example, the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by the following procedure: CsNO3 (1.95 mmol, 0.3806 g) and Al(NO3)3 .9H2O (0.488 mmol, 0.1831 g) were dissolved in 20 mL of H2O. This solution was added dropwisely onto 1.7 g of SiO2 support. The water of the drop solution was evaporated by illuminating a 350 W electric bulb toward SiO2 support containing Cs and Al precursor. After the solution had been completely added, the SiO2 support containing Cs and Al precursor was dried at 110 °C for 12 h. The as-dried sample was then calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. The other Cs8M2/SiO2 catalysts with metals, M, where M = La, Y, Ca, Mg, and Zr, were prepared by using the metal nitrate and CsNO3. 2.2 Catalytic test 1,2-PDO, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP were purchased from Fujifilm Wako Chemicals Corp. They were used for the catalytic reaction without further purification. The catalytic dehydration of 1,2-PDO was performed in a fixed-bed down-flow glass reactor. A catalyst with a weight (W) of 0.15 g was loaded into the reactor. The catalyst was pre-treated in a flow of N2 gas at a reaction temperature for 1 h. 1,2-PDO was fed through the reactor top at a feed rate (F) of 1.8 g h−1 using an N2 carrier gas at a flow rate of 1.8 dm3 h−1. Under the conditions, the contact time (W/F), which is defined as the time taken for the feed reactant to reach the same weight as the catalyst, was calculated to be 0.083 h. The products of the reaction were periodically collected every hour. The liquid products were analyzed with gas chromatography with a mass spectrometer (GC-MS, QP5050A, Shimadzu Corp.) equipped with a capillary column (Inert Cap WAX-HT, a length of 30 m, an inner diameter of 0.32 mm, GL-Sciences Inc.). The liquid products were also quantitatively analyzed with a GC (GC-2014, Shimadzu Corp.) equipped with a 30-m capillary column of WAX-HT and a flame ionization detector using 1-hexanol as an internal standard. Meanwhile, gaseous products, such as propylene, PO, and PAL, were collected in a gas-tight syringe and were analyzed by an off-line GC-8A (Shimadzu Corp.) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a 6-m packed column (VZ-7, GL-Sciences Inc.) using the N2 carrier gas as an internal standard. To clarify the role of base sites, a poisoning experiment was performed in an acidic gas of CO2 at the flow rate of 1.8 dm3 h−1 instead of using N2 carrier gas. Meanwhile, the role of acid sites was investigated by the poisoning experiment using a mixture of NH3 (5 %) and N2 (95 %) at the total flow rate of 1.8 dm3 h−1. In addition, the role of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was investigated using 2,6- and 3,5-DMP as basic probes: 3 wt% of either 2,6- or 3,5-DMP was dissolved in the fed 1,2-PDO and the catalytic test was conducted in the N2 flow of 1.8 dm3 h−1. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystal phase of the catalyst was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using D8 ADVANCE (Bruker Japan Corp.) with Cu K-alpha radiation. The SA was measured by the N2-adsorption analysis technique using a self-made glass. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was conducted with an infrared spectrophotometer (IRAﬃnity-1S, Shimazu Corp.). The sample was diluted in KBr with a weight percentage of 5 wt%. The diluted sample was pressed to form a thin disk in a sample holder, and then an FT-IR spectrum was collected at the wavenumber range between 400 and 4000 cm−1. The differential FT-IR spectrum was automatically obtained by subtracting the background spectrum of KBr from the spectra of samples. The transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were obtained using a H-7650A transmission electron microscope (Hitachi Corp.) at an accelerating voltage of 100 kV. The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 and CO2 (NH3- and CO2-TPD), which was used to investigate the acid and base properties of the catalyst, was performed using BELCATII (MicrotracBEL Corp.). In a typical measurement, a sample with a weight of 0.05 g was pre-heated at 500 °C for 1 h. The sample was cooled to 100 °C and a gas (NH3 or CO2) was introduced for 1 h. The NH3 or CO2 was flushed out by a flow of He gas. The desorption of either NH3 or CO2 was monitored while the temperature of the sample was raised from 100 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The desorbed gas was monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Since the TCD can detect other gases desorbed from the catalyst, a blank TPD was also monitored without the adsorption of CO2 and NH3, as the original TCD signals shown in Figs. S1A and S1B. The difference between the TCD signal in the adsorbed TPD and the blank one was converted using a molar sensitivity of either CO2 or NH3 to obtain the TPD profile. The amounts of acid and base sites were estimated from the integral of the desorption profiles of NH3 and CO2, respectively. The thermal decomposition of gaseous species from the sample was monitored with thermal decomposition with mass analysis (TD-MS) technique using BELCATII with BELMASS unit (MicrotracBEL Corp.) equipped with TCD and a quadruple mass analyzer. The detailed procedure is as follows: the sample of 0.05 g was pre-heated at 500 °C for 1 in a flow of He to remove the physisorbed species. The sample was cooled to 100 °C and then the decomposition of the gaseous species from the sample was monitored while the sample was heated from 100 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The thermogravimetry (TG) was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku Corp.). A sample with a weight of 0.03 g was pre-heated in air at 110 °C for 1 h to remove the physisorbed water. Then, the sample was heated from 110 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 while monitoring the weight change. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effect of metal Initially, the catalytic activity of Cs8M2/SiO2 catalysts was investigated in the dehydrative epoxidation of 1,2-PDO to PO at 400 °C and a W/F of 0.083 h. Fig. 1 shows the change in conversion and selectivity with time on steam (TOS) of several Cs8M2/SiO2 catalysts in the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO, while the numerical data is shown in Table S1. The 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst without M modification was active in the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO; however, the activity steeply decreased, giving an average 1,2-PDO conversion of 15.6 % and PO selectivity of 77.9 mol% ( Table 1). The addition of basic metal oxides, such as La-, Y-, Ca-, and Mg-based oxides, increased the average conversion of 1,2-PDO (Table S1, entries 2 – 5) due to the improvement of catalyst stability (Fig. 1A). Nevertheless, the addition of La, Y, Ca, and Mg decreased the average selectivity to PO. The addition of acidic metal oxides, such as Zr- and Al-based oxides improved the catalytic activity and stability of the Cs/SiO2 (Fig. 1A), while not substantially altering the selectivity to PO. Even though the 15Cs8Zr2/SiO2 catalyst gave a slightly higher conversion of 1,2-PDO than the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst, it had a lower PO selectivity (Table 1). Due to this reason, further investigation was performed using Cs8Al x /SiO2 with high PO selectivity as a catalyst model. To investigate the role of Al in the formation of PO, the Al/SiO2 catalyst without Cs component was tested in the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO (Table 1 and Fig. S2A). Even though the Al/SiO2 catalyst gave a remarkable conversion of 1,2-PDO, it failed to generate PO since the major product was PAL. The presence of Al on SiO2 support generates acid sites, which catalyze the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PAL [29,30]. On the other hand, the PO formation has been reported to be catalyzed by base sites. Therefore, it is reasonable that the Al/SiO2 catalyst hardly produced PO, while it majorly generated PAL. It has been reported that the K/SiO2 catalyst is active for the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO [21]. Thus, we also prepared and explored the performance of the K/SiO2 catalyst in the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO in our catalytic system. Table 1 (entry 5) and Fig. S2B reveal that despite being active, the performance of the K/SiO2 catalyst was inferior to the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst under the same reaction conditions. 3.2 Textural properties of Cs8Alx/SiO2 catalyst Fig. 2A shows the XRD profiles of the 15Cs8Al x /SiO2 catalysts. Strong peaks associated with the CsNO3 phase are visible in the Cs/SiO2 catalyst without Al. The peaks corresponding to the CsNO3 phase diminish as the molar component of Al, x, increases. Wang et al. have reported that the disappearance of the CsNO3 peaks originates from the dispersion of Cs species which is promoted by the existence of Al species [26]. In addition, it has also been reported that the addition of the second metal into the Cs/SiO2 catalyst could promote the decomposition of CsNO3 species [31]. Fig. 2B shows the XRD profiles of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts calcined at different temperatures. The as-dried Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst reveals clear peaks corresponding to the CsNO3 phase. The increase in the calcination temperature to 500 °C decreases the intensity of the CsNO3 peaks, indicating that the calcination process facilitates the decomposition of CsNO3 species. Further increment of the calcination temperature to 700 °C fully decomposes the CsNO3 species as the peaks associated with the CsNO3 phase completely disappear. Fig. 2C depicts the XRD profiles of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts with different Cs8Al2 content. The Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts with Cs8Al2 content of 10 wt% or lower have no peaks of CsNO3 phase, which indicates that the decomposition of CsNO3 species at a low Cs8Al2 content could be completed by calcination at 500 °C for 3 h. In addition, a low content of Cs8Al2 might provide a better dispersion of Cs and Al species, leading to the absence of peaks associated with Cs species. However, the peaks attributed to the CsNO3 phase are visible for the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst with the Cs8Al2 content of 15 wt% or higher. Even though the presence of Al could promote the decomposition of CsNO3 species, the calcination at 500 °C for 3 h for high content of Cs8Al2 might not be sufficient. As a result, the peaks ascribed to the CsNO3 phase are still visible even after the calcination process. In addition, high Cs8Al2 content could also promote the aggregation of Cs species, and this behavior could intensify the diffraction peaks. The TD-MS spectra of several Cs8Al x /SiO2 catalysts were analyzed to verify the decomposition of the CsNO3 species. Fig. 3 depicts the signal corresponding to NO species (m/z = 30) originating from the decomposition of nitrate residue. The signals for other species are illustrated in Fig. S3. The signal of the NO species was intense in the as-dried Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst, indicating the abundance of CsNO3 species. This behavior is strongly in line with the finding from the XRD patterns (Fig. 2B). The NO peak in the TD-MS spectra diminishes after the calcination at 500 °C for 3 h, implying that the calcination process facilitates incomplete decomposition of nitrate species. Notably, the Al promotes the decomposition of CsNO3 species as the NO peak in the Cs8Al4/SiO2 catalyst is substantially lower than Cs8Al2/SiO2 after calcined at the same temperature of 500 °C. The calcination at 700 °C for 3 h completely decomposed CsNO3 species since the signal of NO species is no longer observed. The progress of the decomposition of CsNO3 species with calcination temperature is further corroborated by the TG profiles of the as-dried Cs8Al2/SiO2, which indicate that the weight loss is completed by heat treatment at 600 °C or higher (Fig. S4). Fig. 4 depicts the effect of x on the SA of 15Cs8Al x /SiO2 calcined at 500 °C. The increase in x increases the SA of the resulting catalysts, which is similar to that of the previous report [25,26]. It has been suggested that the enlargement of the SA is contributed by the porosity of the Al components [26]. Even though high calcination temperature was proven to decompose the CsNO3 species efficiently (Figs. 2B and 3), it led to a substantial decrement in the SA: the SA of 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 calcined at 700 °C was 39.1 m2 g−1. Considering that the XRD patterns of Cs8Al2/SiO2 calcined at 700 °C have no peaks associated with Cs and Al components, it can be said that the Cs and Al components remain highly dispersed on SiO2 support. Nonetheless, high calcination temperature might lead to the condensation of the silanol group and the destruction of SiO2 support, which decreased the SA of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst [20,28]. Fig. 5 shows the FT-IR spectra of 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts. The bands at 807 and 1137 cm−1 are assigned to Si-O-Si vibration, while the bands at 3460 and 1654 cm−1 indicate the presence of the adsorbed water [31–33]. The stretching vibration of Si-OH is observed at 970 cm−1 [31–33]. Aside from the vibration associated with SiO2 support, the anti-symmetric stretching of the N-O bond, which indicates the presence of nitrate species, also appears at 1346 cm−1 [31]. Fig. 5 reveals that the vibration band corresponding to adsorbed water at 3460 and 1654 cm−1 did not change after the addition of Cs and Cs+Al precursors before calcination at 500 °C. However, a significant decrement in band intensity was observed after the as-dried samples were calcined at 500 °C, implying that the calcination process promotes the desorption of water from the as-dried samples. It is worth noting that the vibration band intensity associated with nitrate species also diminished after the calcination at 500 °C even though it did not completely disappear. This finding is in line with the XRD patterns shown in Fig. 2B, which demonstrates that the nitrate species still remained even after calcination at 500 °C. The FT-IR spectra also provide a glimpse of how Cs might anchor on SiO2 support. The vibration band of Si-OH located at 970 cm−1 was still visible after the addition of Cs and Cs+Al precursors. Nevertheless, this band fully disappeared after the as-dried samples were calcined at 500 °C. The disappearance of this band has been reported as an indication of the consumption of Si-OH due to the replacement of H in Si-OH with a metal cation, i.e., Cs+ or Al3+ [31,32,34]. Considering that the vibration band of 970 cm−1 was still visible before calcination, it can be said that the formation of Si-O-Cs or Si-O-Al can only proceed with the help of heat treatment. It is also worth noting that the vibration band associated with the OH group of water in the calcined 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts remained low even though the sample was not evacuated in a vacuum prior to the FT-IR measurement. This finding implies that the re-hydration of SiO2 and Cs-species did not occur. In addition, the band corresponding to Si-OH at 970 cm−1 did not re-emerge after calcination, suggesting that the Si-O-Cs or Si-O-Al moiety was stable even under air exposure. Fig. 6 illustrates the TEM images of the fresh 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts. Similar to the previous reports [20,31], no clear crystallite CsNO3 or Cs2O phase was observed in both fresh 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts. Even though the peaks associated with the CsNO3 phase were visible in the XRD patterns of the 15.8Cs/SiO2 shown in Fig. 2A, the CsNO3 crystals were not visible in the TEM image (Fig. 6A). Similar behavior has also been reported by Li et al., where the TEM image of 10Cs/SiO2 only reveals the amorphous nature of SiO2 support even though the peaks corresponding to the CsNO3 phase are observed in the XRD profiles [31]. Similar to that of the fresh 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst, the TEM image of the fresh 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst does not show any crystal associated with CsNO3. Even though the peaks assigned to the CsNO3 phase in the XRD profiles of the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 2A – 2D) are not as intense as those in the 15.8Cs/SiO2, these peaks can still be observed. It has been mentioned that Al promoted the decomposition of CsNO3, nevertheless, the product of the decomposition of the CsNO3 species still cannot be observed in the TEM image (Fig. 6B). The acid-base properties of the 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts were investigated by the NH3- and CO2-TPD. Fig. 7A and 7B shows the NH3- and CO2-TPD profiles of 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts, respectively. The 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst mainly contains weak acid and base sites as the NH3 and CO2 desorption peak is primarily located below 300 °C. Notably, the addition of Al species did not substantially alter the concentration of the acid sites as the amount of the desorbed NH3 between 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts was identical. Nevertheless, a substantial decrement in base concentration was observed due to the addition of Al as the amount of desorbed CO2 in the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst was substantially lower than that in the Cs/SiO2 catalyst. It should be noted that the decrement in the base site concentration was mainly caused by the reduction of the concentration of strong base sites, as the signals located at a temperature higher than 300 °C were diminished. This result suggests that the presence of Al species reduces the strong base sites in the Cs/SiO2 but keeps the weak base sites intact. 3.3 Catalytic dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO over Cs8Alx/SiO2 catalysts Fig. 8A demonstrates the catalytic activity of several 15Cs8Al x /SiO2 catalysts in the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO at 400 °C and a W/F of 0.083 h while Table S2 lists the numerical data. Fig. S5 displays the changes in conversion and selectivity with TOS of the Cs8Al x /SiO2 catalysts. The Cs/SiO2 catalyst was still active in converting 1,2-PDO to PO, giving 1,2-PDO conversion and PO selectivity of 15.6 % and 77.9 mol%, respectively. The increment of x, i.e., the addition of Al component, from 0 to 1 substantially improved the catalytic activity of the resulting catalyst. Previous reports have suggested that the improvement of Cs dispersion due to the presence of Al could be the origin of the increment of catalytic activity [25,26]. However, the XRD patterns in Fig. 2A show that the difference in CsNO3 peak intensity between Cs/SiO2 and Cs8Al1/SiO2 catalysts is not significant. Furthermore, Al has been proven to promote the decomposition of CsNO3 species; thus, the decrement in CsNO3 peak intensity might not originate from the difference in Cs dispersion. It is also worth noting that the selectivity to PO is slightly enhanced with the addition of Al. However, the Al component might not directly participate in the formation of PO, since the presence of Al on SiO2 support without Cs species only led to a substantial production of PAL (Table 1, entry 4). A minor decline in the conversation of 1,2-PDO and PO selectivity was observed with a further increment of x from 1 to 4. This behavior was due to a slight decline in the Cs molar component with the increase in x. Concurrently, the increase in x also increased Al species on SiO2 which slightly enhanced the formation of PAL. Fig. 8B illustrates the effect of Cs8Al2 content on the catalytic activity of aCs8Al2/SiO2 at 400 °C and a W/F of 0.083 h while Table S3 presents the numerical data. Fig. S6 displays the changes in conversion and selectivity with TOS over the aCs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts. The conversion of 1,2-PDO increased from 15.6 % to 56 % as the Cs8Al2 content increased. However, the increase in the Cs8Al2 content decreased the selectivity to PO from 85.3 % to 75.4 %. Concurrently, the decrement in PO selectivity was accompanied by the increase in the selectivity to PAL and AAL. An abundant Cs8Al2 species at a high Cs8Al2 content facilitated the production of PO efficiently; nevertheless, rapid production of PO with the existence of abundant Cs8Al2 also increased the rate of PO isomerization to AAL. Competitively, abundant Cs8Al2 species also gave a slight increase in the rate of 1,2-PDO dehydration to PAL. Due to these reasons, it is reasonable that the selectivity of PO slightly decreased with the increase in the Cs8Al2 content. It is worth mentioning that despite a slight increment of PAL and AAL production, the overall yield of PO still increased with the increment of Cs8Al2 content. Fig. 8C shows the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity of 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 at a W/F of 0.083 h while Table S4 presents the numerical data. Fig. S7 displays the changes in conversion and PO selectivity with TOS over the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst at different temperatures. The increase in the reaction temperature increased the conversion of 1,2-PDO. The selectivity to PO increased when the reaction temperature was increased from 350 to 400 °C; however, further increment of reaction temperature to 450 °C declined the selectivity to PO. This phenomenon was caused by the increase in the rate of side reactions, such as the isomerization of PO to AAL and the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PAL. The investigation of the reaction temperature suggests that a mild reaction temperature of 400 °C provided a preferable condition for the transformation of 1,2-PDO to PO. Fig. 8D illustrates the effect of W/F on the catalytic activity of 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 at 400 °C while Table S5 lists the numerical data. Fig. S8 displays the changes in conversion and PO selectivity with TOS over the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst at different W/F. Prolonging the W/F facilitated the consumption of 1,2-PDO; nevertheless, it was accompanied by a decrement in PO selectivity. Concurrently, the selectivity to AAL and PAL increased with the increase in W/F. Similar to the increase in Cs8Al2 content, an abundant catalyst amount, i.e., high W/F, gave rise to the rate of side reaction, especially PO isomerization and 1,2-PDO dehydration to PAL. 3.4 Long-run performance of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst Fig. 9 shows the long-run performance of the 15Cs8Al x /SiO2 catalysts at 400 °C and a W/F of 0.167 h. The 1,2-PDO conversion over the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al1/SiO2 catalysts was stable for a TOS of 10 h (Fig. 9B and 9C), showcasing that the addition of Al component on the 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst contributed to the stability of the catalyst. The 1,2-PDO conversion over the 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst without Al component significantly decreased under a prolonged TOS, despite the high selectivity to PO (Fig. 9A). Fig. S9 shows the TG profiles of the fresh and spent 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts. The fresh 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst shows a substantial weight change at high temperatures (>700 °C) due to the decomposition of CsNO3 species (Fig. S9A). Since Section 3.2 mentions that the presence of Al promoted the decomposition of CsNO3 species, it is reasonable that the 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst still contained a substantial amount of CsNO3 species even after the calcination at 500 °C. In contrast to the 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst, the weight change of the fresh 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst was substantially lower, due to the promotion effect of Al in the decomposition of CsNO3 species during the calcination process at 500 °C. Fig. S9 also shows the TG profiles of the spent 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts. The spent 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst contained less coke than the 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst after the 10-h run test. Fig. 4 reveals that the SA of the catalyst decreases with TOS. Substantial decrement of SA of 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 proceeded at the initial stage of the reaction: the SA of the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 reduced from 140.3 to 95.7 m2 g−1 after a short TOS of 0.5 h while that of the 15.8Cs/SiO2 reduced from 98.9 to 44.0 m2 g−1. After a TOS of 10 h, the SA of 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 (75.1 m2 g−1) was substantially larger than that of 15.8Cs/SiO2 (14.6 m2 g−1). The TEM images clearly show that the morphology of the fresh and spent 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalysts is significantly different after a TOS of 10 h (Fig. 6A and 6C). In contrast, the morphology of the fresh and spent 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts were relatively similar (Fig. 6B and 6D). It is reasonable to assume that the presence of Al allows the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 to maintain its morphology. The significant change in catalyst morphology could be the origin of a more severe catalyst deactivation in the 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst. Moreover, Fig. 4 and Fig. S9 clearly show that 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 had substantially larger SA and less coke than 15.8Cs/SiO2 even after prolonged reaction. Thus, it is reasonable that 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 is more stable than 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst without Al. Fig. 2D shows the XRD pattern of the fresh and spent 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts after the long-run test. The peaks associated with the CsNO3 phase disappeared in both 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts after the long-run test at 400 °C for 10 h. This phenomenon was caused by the rapid decomposition of the CsNO3 phase under the reaction conditions. To verify this assumption, the XRD patterns of the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst were analyzed after the reaction was performed for 0.5 and 5 h. Fig. S10A reveals that the diffraction peaks of the CsNO3 phase had completely disappeared after the catalyst was employed for the reaction at a TOS of 0.5 h, which was further corroborated by the reduction of NO species (m/z = 30) in the TD-MS spectra of the spent 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst after being used for a TOS of 0.5 and 5 h (Fig. S10B). This behavior is also corroborated further by the FT-IR spectra of the spent catalysts (Fig. 5). The vibration band associated with the N-O bond was no longer visible in the spent 15.8Cs/SiO2 and 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalysts, implying that the nitrate species had been decomposed. It can be said that the CsNO3 phase might be decomposed during the catalytic process, even though the decomposition did not decrease the catalytic activity. Therefore, the CsNO3 species was not the active species for the formation of PO from 1,2-PDO. 3.5 Poisoning experiment: the role of acid and base in the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst The role of acid and base sites of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst was investigated by the poisoning experiment. Fig. 7 reveals the presence of the acid and base sites of the 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst. To further investigate the role of the acid and base sites during the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO, poisoning experiments using several molecules, such as NH3, CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP, were performed. Fig. 10 demonstrates the catalytic activity of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst in the presence of CO2 gas, which can hinder access to base sites. A substantial decrement in the yield of PO due to CO2 poisoning was observed, indicating that the base sites were essential for the formation of PO. Even though the addition of the Al component reduced the concentration of the base sites (Fig. 7), it clearly improved the catalytic activity of the Cs/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 8A). It can be assumed that the addition of Al did not completely reduce the base site concentration as the weak base site at the region below 300 °C was still clearly observed (Fig. 7B). This finding suggests that the addition of Al into the Cs/SiO2 catalyst mainly reduced the concentration of the strong base site. Considering that the formation of PO from 1,2-PDO could still proceed over weak base sites [21], the reduction of strong base site concentration due to the addition of Al did not give a substantial decrement in catalytic activity. Nevertheless, the excessive amount of Al component could slightly reduce the Cs species, which reduces the number of base sites, leading to a small decrement in catalytic activity (Fig. 8A). The presence of NH3 gas, which can block access to acid sites, had a negligible effect on the catalytic activity of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst ( Fig. 10), implying that the acid sites were not involved during catalytic reactions. Similarly, the activity of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst in the presence of 2,6-DMP, which can poison Brønsted acid sites [35–37], was identical to that of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst without any poison. Therefore, the Brønsted acid sites might not play a crucial role in the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO. However, the poisoning experiment using 3,5-DMP, which can be used to investigate the role of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [38,39], decreased the yield of PO, implying that the Lewis acid sites might participate in the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO. The contradictive results between 3,5-DMP and NH3 poisonings were yet to be understood. Fig. S11 illustrates the effect of poison on the selectivity of PO, while Table S6 summarizes the effect of poison on the overall selectivity of the products. The selectivity to PO declined in the presence of CO2, while the selectivity to PAL increased. The hindrance to base sites could expose the acid sites to 1,2-PDO, which is favorable for the PAL formation. Notably, the overall selectivity of the product in the presence of NH3, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP was not substantially different from the reaction without any poison. This finding indicates that the hindrance to acid sites had no significant impact on product distribution. The result of the poisoning experiment strongly implies that the base sites of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst act as the active sites in the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO. Previously, the detailed mechanism of dehydration of 2,3-butanediol to 2,3-epoxybutane has been described by density functional theory, where the base sites act as the active sites [20]. The base site originates from the basic O near Cs+ species, in which the distance between basic O and Cs+ is similar to that in the Cs2O species. It is then reasonable to assume that the CsNO3 might decompose during the reaction to form Cs2O-like species on SiO2 support and the basic O in that Cs2O acts as the active site for the formation of PO. This assumption is also corroborated by the fact that CsNO3 rapidly disappeared during the catalytic test (Fig. S10), but the disappearance of this CsNO3 species did not reduce the catalytic activity. Furthermore, the vibration band of Si-OH located at 970 cm−1 remained absent in the spent catalysts (Fig. 5), demonstrating that the Si-O-Cs or Si-O-Al was stable even after exposure to the reaction conditions at a long TOS of 10 h. It can be assumed that the Cs-species, which is the origin for the base sites, remains intact on SiO2 support, allowing the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO to proceed even after prolonged TOS. In line with this finding, we have also demonstrated that the CsH2PO4/SiO2 catalyzes the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to AAL [22]. The AAL formation is initiated by the formation of PO over the base sites, which consecutively isomerizes to AAL over the acid and base sites of the catalyst. Considering that the role of acid sites of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst was negligible, while only base sites played an essential role in the PO formation, it is reasonable that the AAL selectivity is minor since the isomerization of PO to AAL requires the active role of acid and base sites. Furthermore, the increase of Al molar component, x, increased the AAL and PAL selectivity, indicating that the rise in acid site concentration facilitates the isomerization and dehydration to PAL (Table S2). Therefore, this work also confirms the plausible mechanism that the isomerization of PO to AAL proceeds via an acid-base concerted mechanism. 4 Conclusions The vapor-phase dehydration of 1,2-PDO to produce PO over CsAl/SiO2 catalysts was investigated. The addition of Al component into Cs/SiO2 catalyst improved the catalytic activity. The presence of the Al component facilitated the decomposition of the CsNO3 species and maintained the morphology of the CsAl/SiO2 catalyst during the catalytic reaction. The presence of Al also reduced the concentration of strong base, while keeping the weak base intact. The addition of Al at an optimum molar ratio to Cs improved the catalytic activity while keeping the rate of side reactions, such as the formation of PAL and AAL, low. Even though the conversion of 1,2-PDO could be increased by increasing the reaction temperature, W/F, and Cs8Al2 content, optimum conditions were still required to ensure efficient formation of PO. The spent CsAl/SiO2 catalysts had a substantially larger SA than the spent Cs/SiO2 catalyst at a prolonged TOS of 10 h. The presence of Al in 15Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst was proven to keep the morphology of the catalyst after the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to PO. The absence of Al led to a substantial change in the morphology of the spent 15.8Cs/SiO2 catalyst. These properties contributed to the high stability of the CsAl/SiO2 catalyst. Additionally, the spent CsAl/SiO2 catalysts contained fewer carbonaceous species than the spent Cs/SiO2 catalyst due to a lower rate of coke formation. The poisoning experiment using CO2 gas revealed the importance of the base sites of the Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst. On the other hand, the role of acid sites was negligible as confirmed by the poisoning experiment using NH3 and 2,6-DMP. coredata.dc:description: The introduction of Al into SiO2-supported cesium oxide (Cs/SiO2) promoted catalytic activity for the dehydration of 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) to propylene oxide (PO). This improvement was attributed to the promotion of CsNO3 decomposition and the ability of Al to keep the morphology of the SiO2-supported catalyst, even though the Al component slightly reduced the concentration of the base site. The optimum molar component of Al was proven to improve the activity of Cs/SiO2 catalyst, while maintaining a low rate of side reactions, such as isomerization of PO to allyl alcohol and dehydration of 1,2-PDO to propanal. Several parameters, such as reaction temperature, contact time, Cs8Al2 content, and Al molar component influenced catalytic activity and product distributions. The poisoning experiment by use of CO2 revealed the importance of the base sites of Cs8Al2/SiO2 catalyst, while the role of acid sites was negligible as confirmed by the poisoning experiment with NH3.

coredata.dc:title: Promotion effect of Al species on silica-supported cesium oxide catalyst in the vapor-phase dehydration of 1,2-propanediol to propylene oxide
